content: In your Thunderbird go to menu Help > Troubleshooting Information > Profile Folder > Show in Finder, then quit TB. In the TB profile folder (probably named somewhat like abcd1234.default-release) go to folder "Mail" and open it. You should see a sub-folder "Local Folders". Make a screen shot of the contents of Local Folders.
creator: Mapenzi

kitty6 said

I'm not a magician and don't know the secret formula to bring back your missing folders unless you find a recent backup copy of your Thunderbird profile folder. Do you use TimeMachine?

And since I cannot look over your shoulder on your Mac screen I have to ask for screen shots. Your missing data are not visible in Local Folders, so I continue to search somewhere else and ask questions which you might consider as superfluous or even stupid.

I don't know what happened during your TB update. You describe that "I now have two accounts appearing in my Thunderbird sidebar. One is my email address with Inbox in the dropdown, nothing else." This is not normal! If you only had an IMAP account before the update, where does the second account come from? Did TB after the update start with a request to set up "your existing email address"? But you are very certain that in folder "Profiles" there is no second profile folder that you won't verify?

The contents of the "smart mailboxes" in your "Mail" folder tells me that you are using (or have been using) a so-called "saved search" or other virtual folder with the name "tags". Maybe in your Local Folders you created such a virtual folder containing sub-folders ?

content:
kitty6 said
What’s next? I looked there for Local Folders, Mail, Thunderbird… Didn’t find these.

It's a long way to go!! Look at my screen shot from March 5th: select a Time Machine backup (a date) made shortly before the loss of your Local Folders. Then go to Macintosh Data > Users > username > Library > Thunderbird > Profiles > profile name >Mail > Local Folders (see image with path to Local Folders in Time Machine) Copy the folder "Local Folders" to your Desktop.

In Thunderbird via Help go to Troubleshooting Info > Profile Folder > Show in Finder as described in my first reply, then quit TB. Go to the "Mail" folder and delete Local Folders. Then drag the "Local Folders" backup which you just copied from Time Machine to your Desktop and drag it in the folder "Mail" in your actual profile folder. Restart TB and report good news (i hope so!)

content: HTML messages have start and stop tags for beginning and ending various styles, such as font, bold, italics. if you paste text in that has its own HTML tags, those may overlay existing tags and following text may appear with the style settings of the posted text. To avoid that, use the paste without formatting option.
creator: davidsk

content: Given the ever improving features for writing emails, can't a "format painter" option be added so that text formatting is simpler?
creator: cheryl9

content: Not really, as email is sent as basic text by internet design. HTML provides the attributes to be applied to the text when received. Paslting without formatting is a good strategy to then adjust formatting afterwards.

content:
re : I would love to set "CTRL + E" to place a cursor on the search bar

Thunderbird has three different types of search and each has it's own uses for different circumstances. 'Ctrl+ K' - this is the Global search 'Ctrl+Shift+K' is the quick filter search on selected folder 'Ctrl+Shift+F' is the 'Find' > 'Search Messages' option

'Ctrl+E' is already preset - 'Edit as new message' (an option available on drop down menu when you right click on an email in list)

Maybe it's time to get used to new shortcut options because it's not so simple to just change the use of one item. I did not find it too difficult; just a bit frustrating for a couple of days then it got easier.

I found this was a Link to good info on Thunderbird Shortcuts, worth bookmarking.

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/keyboard-shortcuts-thunderbird

If you enable the 'Menu Bar' then you will find many of the shortcuts are mentioned. Menu app icon (3 lines) > 'View' > 'Toolbars' > select 'Menu Bar'

The 'Menu Bar' is not enabled by default but can be important for various reasons, so I would advise you enable it.

content:
Je tiež možné, že už je preplnený priečinok "Doručená pošta" a možno aj "Odoslaná pošta", kde je Thunderbirdom stanovený maximálny objem 4GB (rovnako ako aj pre každý samostatný priečinok). Kliknite na priečinok "Doručená pošta" pravým tlačidlom myši, vyberte "Vlastnosti" a preverte akú veľkosť na disku zaberá. Limit veľkosti zložky je detailnejšie vysvetlený tuná: http://kb.mozillazine.org/Limits_%28Thunderbird%29#Folders_and_messages.

Odporúčam staré správy z preplneného priečinka "Doručená pošta" a "Odoslaná pošta" odstrániť, alebo archivovať.

content: 1. Click Address Book to open it. 2. Select the mailing list. 3. On the central panel, select the email addresses which you want to send email to. If you want to select multiple email addresses, you can select them with ctrl or shift key pressed. 4.1. Right-click on one of the email addresses you have selected. Then click "Write". OR 4.2. Click "Write" on the right panel. (Please see the attached image.)
creator: Yu5tiqX9og

content:
Thanks Yu5tiqX9og for the quick & helpful reply; sorry I haven't responded earlier (I expected an email to tell me that there was a reply but none came. Your method works well for sending to one or two people in the mailing list - and showed me how to send to most in the list. For that, I'd amend your method slightly as follows (added for anyone else with this need.)

1 Click Address Book to open it. 2 Select (click) on the mailing list - the list of email names will appear in a central panel. 3 On the central panel, select (click) on any of the email addresses, then press Ctrl and A (together.) This will select all of the addresses in a right-hand panel, and above them "Write" / "Event" / "New List" 4 Click "Write" on the right-hand panel, and a new email will open. 5 All the email addresses will appear in the To: field - and any that are not required can be deleted.

content:
You are using an IMAP gmail account. Gmail does not need to have the 'Account Settings ->Copies & Folders, "Place a copy in" selected because by default Gmail will put all sent emails into the server 'Sent' folder which means you auto see them in that 'Sent' imap folder.

If you select 'Place a copy in' then you can also select the checkbox 'Place replies in the folder of the message being replied to'

Then when you click on a 'Reply' to an email (lets say that email was in 'Inbox') and send - whilst you still get a copy in the gmail Sent folder, you will also get a copy put into the same folder which stores the email you replied to eg: Inbox. This is because gmail simply applied the 'Inbox' label to the email which auto had the 'Sent' label applied. This means same email is visible in 2 locations. Be aware - if you delete either and it gets put into the 'Trash' then both get deleted. So if you want to delete one then use the 'Shift+Del' keys and gmail will only remove the appropriate label.
creator: Toad-Hall

I've discovered the same thing. Sometimes it's ok but after a while seems to stop. There has been a bug report of this which you can view here: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1866481

Current work around I've discovered to get it working again: Used 'Unified' toolbar 'Customise' Move it off back into the 'Available for Mail Space Only' section then put it back onto the toolbar - saved not available so did not use - just clicked on Cancel - it returned to normal Mail tab and discovered it was suddenly working ok.

content: This may help, or not. To clarify, thunderbird did not request your password, your email provider did. Thunderbird is just your agent. In an attempt to clear the setup, do this: - check that your password works properly when logging on via website. That's just a sanity check. - in thunderbird, click settings>privacy&security - click saved passwords and then show passwords - now, highlight the rows for the account (normally two) and delete them. This removes whatever passwords were stored. - close and restart thunderbird and try again with the right password. - if that does not work, it may be that your email provider requires an 'app' password instead of the normal password when using a PC email client. Gmail is an example of this.
creator: davidsk
